evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Gregory discussed severe anxiety about networking, specifically emailing Professor Chen. Solutions included: 1) Structured email template focusing on specific research questions 2) Framing inexperience as intellectual curiosity 3) Mock interview preparation. Gregory implemented solutions by sending a tailored email and practicing responses. Progress evidence: He sent the email despite panic, connected coursework to creative research (coffee thermodynamics), and acknowledged needing presentation practice. Though still anxious, he demonstrated increased initiative and problem-solving engagement.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Problems discussed: Networking anxiety (emailing professors), presentation fears, procrastination on career exploration. 2) Solutions offered/accepted: Step-by-step email template, role-playing Q&A practice, humor-based research approach, and sip-pause presentation technique. 3) Student's response: Initially hesitant but implemented email template, engaged in role-play, developed original research concept, and attempted presentation strategies despite discomfort. 4) Evidence of progress: Successfully sent professional email to Dr. Chen, created testable research methodology for coffee thermodynamics, and demonstrated improved self-awareness during practice presentations at campus cafe.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Problems discussed: Networking anxiety (emailing professors), interview preparation fears, GPA concerns, and research presentation anxiety. 2) Solutions offered/accepted: Structured email template with personalization, roleplaying with 3-part answer framework, GPA pivot strategy to practical skills, and bite-sized preparation techniques. 3) Student's response: Implemented email template immediately, successfully applied answer structures during practice, scheduled follow-up session with commitment to bring materials. 4) Evidence of progress: Sent professional email to professor, demonstrated improved interview responses during roleplay, shifted from avoidance ('maybe wait') to action ('sent email'), and reframed perceived weaknesses as assets.

Discussed Gregory's networking anxiety and career concerns. Solutions: 1) Email template with research-specific questions and personal PS, 2) 30-min prep strategy for meetings, 3) GPA redirection to hands-on skills, 4) Presentation sip-pause technique. Gregory responded by: drafting/sending email to Dr. Chen, developing research project methodology, roleplaying professor Q&As, and creating measurement protocols. Progress evidenced by: sent email despite panic, designed Arduino data collection, connected coursework to research, and practiced anxiety management techniques during thermo exam crunch.

Gregory discussed severe networking anxiety preventing professional outreach. Solutions included: 1) Email templates with research-focused questions 2) Role-playing professor interactions 3) Structured preparation limits. Gregory implemented solutions by: drafting/sending email to Dr. Chen, practicing technical responses, and designing measurement protocols for research project. Evidence of progress: sent email despite panic, effectively connected coursework to research during practice, developed testable methodology, and created contingency plans for public interactions. Anxiety decreased from 7→6.5 through concrete skill-building.
